an7.31:1.1: “Mendicants, there are these seven downfalls for a lay follower …
an7.31:1.2: There are these seven successes for a lay follower.
an7.31:1.4: They don’t miss out on seeing the mendicants.
an7.31:1.5: They don’t neglect listening to the true teaching.
an7.31:1.6: They train in higher ethical conduct.
an7.31:1.7: They’re very confident about mendicants, whether senior, junior, or middle.
an7.31:1.8: They don’t listen to the teaching with a hostile, fault-finding mind.
an7.31:1.9: They don’t seek outside of the Buddhist community for those worthy of religious donations.
an7.31:1.10: And they serve the Buddhist community first.
an7.31:1.11: These are the seven successes for a lay follower.
an7.31:2.1: A lay follower misses out on seeing
an7.31:2.3: and listening to the teachings of the Noble One.
an7.31:2.4: They don’t train in higher ethical conduct,
an7.31:3.3: They want to listen to the true teaching
an7.31:4.1: They seek outside the Buddhist community
an7.31:4.2: for someone else worthy of religious donations,
an7.31:5.1: These seven principles leading to decline
an7.31:5.3: A lay follower who practices these
an7.31:5.4: falls away from the true teaching.
an7.31:6.1: A lay follower doesn’t miss out on seeing
an7.31:6.3: and listening to the teachings of the Noble One.
an7.31:6.4: They train in higher ethical conduct,
an7.31:7.3: They want to listen to the true teaching
an7.31:8.1: They don’t seek outside the Buddhist community
an7.31:8.2: for someone else worthy of religious donations,
an7.31:9.1: These seven principles that prevent decline
an7.31:9.3: A lay follower who practices them
an7.31:9.4: doesn’t fall away from the true teaching.”
